text:
OS: Solaris 10

1. i have this numbers
# netstat -an | grep LIST | egrep "22|111|8443|8080"
      *.111                *.*                0      0 49152      0 LISTEN
      *.22                 *.*                0      0 49152      0 LISTEN
      *.8080               *.*                0      0 49152      0 LISTEN
      *.22                 *.*                0      0 49152      0 LISTEN
      *.8443               *.*                0      0 49152      0 LISTEN
      *.22                 *.*                0      0 49152      0 LISTEN      

2. i have this lines in config (others are skipped)
  Listen 8443
  NameVirtualHost 1.2.3.4:8443
  LogLevel debug
  <VirtualHost 1.2.3.4:8443
    ...
  </VirtualHost>

3. i changed 8443 to 8080 and spent several hours to understand why virtualhost doesn't work. I didn't see any warning about socket already in use.

4. After this i've tried others ports that already in use and got warning only for port 22.
(125)Address already in use: make_sock: could not bind to address [::]:22
creator: mike.pechkin@gmail.com
poirier@pobox.com
text: Are you sure you changed Listen and not just the virtual host configuration?  Without the Listen, Apache won't even try to bind to the port.

I'm very sure. 
I've repo this several times.

After changed ports to 22, i can't login to server by putty :)
creator: mike.pechkin@gmail.com

text: if usefull i can try to reproduce under Solaris10+10_Recommended patches.
creator: mike.pechkin@gmail.com

text:
OS: latest Solaris 10+10_Recommended
Sun Studio 12 + latest patches

How to reproduce:
1. rpcbind listen on tcp/111 port
 # netstat -an | grep LIST | grep 111
      *.111                *.*                0      0 49152      0 LISTEN

2. Let's config apache for 111/TCP too + LogLevel debug
# cat ../conf/httpd.conf| egrep "111|LogLevel"   
Listen 111
LogLevel debug
NameVirtualHost 172.25.16.30:111
<VirtualHost 172.25.16.30:111>

3. 
# ./apachectl start         

4. 
# netstat -an | grep LIST | grep 111
      *.111                *.*                0      0 49152      0 LISTEN
      *.111                *.*                0      0 49152      0 LISTEN
      *.111                             *.*                             0      0 49152      0 LISTEN      

5. no warnings in log at all
creator: mike.pechkin@gmail.com

text: Erm, what exactly are you claiming?  It looks from your last netstat as if it bound successfully to *.111.  What happens when you telnet to that port?
creator: nick@webthing.com
mike.pechkin@gmail.com
text:
Kew: As you can see TCP/111 is already used, so apache should output warning and exit.

At the same time if i do telnet to port 111 after step 4 i see no output at all and if i use browser for port 111 i just get standart timeout warning.

Just try to repeat on Solaris 10

creator: covener@gmail.com
text: I believe this is/was a solaris defect.
